content.webTitle: Mark Ronson: some of the most exciting music is coming from Australia

fields.headline: Mark Ronson: some of the most exciting music is coming from Australia
fields.bodyText: British musician and producer Mark Ronson, 39, has been called a musical “magpie” thanks to his uncanny ability to spot rare talent (Lily Allen, Amy Winehouse), often resulting in stellar collaborations. With Ronson visiting Australia, and his recent fascination with Perth musician Kevin Parker of Tame Impala fame, we asked for his take on the local scene. How did your collaboration with Kevin come about? He features quite heavily on your third album, Uptown Special. I loved their band and would always see them play in London. We talked about doing some kind of side project, which never materialised. And then [Kevin] sent me this demo of a funk record he’d been working on. It didn’t even have a name and it was just so cool. When I started working on my album, I had some ideas for some songs and kept hearing his voice in my head. I asked if he would come down to Memphis and just hang out. Obviously he’s in one of the biggest bands in the world; they’re always touring and I think their album had just been named in every single best album of the year list. So for him to take a week out of his life to come to Memphis was pretty awesome. Not only did he sing the songs, just having him around – the way he plays drums, his voice on background harmonies, all the little touches that he added – just made everything a little bit cooler and better. It sounds like quite a different Kevin Parker on your album compared with his work with Tame Impala. Did hearing that funk demo help open up those possibilities? For me, his voice is always the most defining element of the music. As soon as I hear his voice it feels like Tame Impala. I guess to some people it does sound like a departure from that stuff but for me it just sounds like him and that makes it cool. Can you describe the qualities of his voice that make it so special? It’s ethereal, detached and angelic. A lot of my favourite music is like that – there’s something so pure in his delivery, but it’s overwhelmingly melancholy, like Lonerism. You also invited Australian musician Kirin J Callinan to play on the album. Yeah, I saw him play at the wedding of this Australian skateboard legend named Dustin Dollin in Paris. He sung INXS’s Never Tear Us Apart in the church after the ceremony. It was pretty beautiful with the organ. Then I went back to the wedding party and he also played. It’s a wedding so you’d expect the bands to start playing Earth, Wind and Fire and Beyoncé. [Instead] he had 30 Roland guitar pedals around him and this amp. It blew everyone’s minds. Afterwards I said: “I have this song that I think you will be great to play solo on, would you come if you happen to be in London?” I honestly don’t know anybody else who could have played what he played because that song is really unique to him. He’s a pretty monster musician, and an incredible performer! We DJ’d together last night, back-to-back. He’d be playing the most crazy techno remix of Game of Thrones, or Savage Garden’s I Want You, or a hip-hop record. Are there any other Australian musicians you’d be interested in working with in the future? I couldn’t say because I don’t know who would be interested in working with me, but there’s certainly some amazing talent coming out of here – more than any other time I can really remember. Some of the most exciting music is coming from Australia – like Jagwar Ma. There’s been a lot of discussion recently surrounding Iggy Azalea and her appropriation – possibly misappropriation – of African American culture. You’ve worked with many great African American artists – do you ever feel you face similar challenges? Ever since I started DJing in hip-hop clubs in New York this was the music I loved. And I’ve never really pretended to be anything that I’m not. Never pretended to be hood when I’m not. And maybe that’s why I’ve just been accepted – I’m not really sure. At the same time, I’m very respectful and I understand where it all comes from. That was part of going through the South – going to those churches – really understanding the roots of this music that we love, because it’s really hard to remember that every single genre of music pretty much nowadays comes from American black music: so jazz, soul, gospel, funk, which then became hip-hop; pop music came from rock ’n’ roll which was from there too. Of course, there’s a little bit of European influence with classical chords but for the most part it is from African American culture. You got to be respectful of your place within something that you didn’t really create, but it’s the thing that I love the most and I wouldn’t know what else to do. You’re famous for collaborations. It it a case of recognising star quality in someone, or more about feeling a connection? When it starts I’m only thinking about the music. Who’s the best person for this song? And that’s it. You’re listening and writing a song and thinking, “man, you know whose voice would sound really good over this?” In the case of Keyonne Starr – the singer we met in Jackson, Mississippi, and put on the record – we wrote a song and couldn’t think of anyone to sing it. So Jeff [Bhasker] was like: “Let’s go drive to the South and find someone.” It sounds so hokey but the music tells you what you need to get. Much the same way a director works with a team of actors, cinematographers and editors? It’s not a bad analogy. I think so many producers do different things. In the hip-hop context, Timbaland and RZA, they make the music and then the singer or the rapper does their thing. Rick Rubin probably has a vision – he’s not so hands-on in the studio with equipment and gear but gets these amazing performances out of people and gives people guidance in making a record. It’s different for me because it can vary song to song but I kind of write the music, or at least co-write it, and then do the arrangements, play the instrumentation and engineer it. So you’re doing a lot of the little roles: half boom operator, half casting agent, half screen writer and then half actor if you’re playing on it. Maybe you’re not the lead actor – like in Uptown Funk I would be Robert Duvall in the Godfather. I’m not Pacino, but you’re doing an important part that holds it down. • Mark Ronson’s third album Uptown Special is out now
